Tuan Chau Island was our second stop after Hang Luon, and I can confidently say it's a must-visit destination. The highlight here is the massive limestone cave - an extraordinary natural wonder. The stunning formations inside the cave are truly breathtaking and worth the experience. However, a friendly but important warning: if you're not ready for a bit of physical effort - like walking up steps, going through a long cave path, and getting down into the island - think twice before getting off. Once you step out, the cruise won't wait. It will sail to the other side of the island to pick you up. That means you must complete the entire walk through the cave to reach the exit point where the cruise will be waiting. So, make sure you're physically ready for a bit of walk, but totally worth it!

reviews.text:
Titop Island is an absolute gem in Ha Long Bay, offering both stunning views and a beautiful beach. This small island is a popular stop for cruise ships, and it's easy to see why. Whether you're into hiking, swimming, or just soaking in breathtaking scenery, Titop has something for everyone.

For those who love a challenge, the climb to the top of the mountain is a must. It's about 400 steps to the summit, and while the hike can be steep and demanding, the panoramic view from the top is absolutely worth the effort. The sight of Ha Long Bay from above, with its emerald waters and scattered islands, is truly awe-inspiring and makes the climb more than rewarding.

If you prefer a more relaxed experience, the island's beach is a great place to unwind. The white sand is soft and clean, continuously washed by the tide, and the water is clear and inviting for a swim. Whether you choose to lounge on a deckchair or take a dip in the sea, the beach offers a peaceful escape from the bustling tourist spots.

The island also holds historical significance, named after a Russian general who helped Vietnam during the war, adding a unique cultural layer to the visit.

Overall, Titop Island is a must-visit destination in Ha Long Bay. Whether you're climbing to the top for a breathtaking view or relaxing on the pristine beach, this island offers an unforgettable experience. Highly recommended for anyone exploring the bay!

places.generalDescription: Bai Tu Long Bay is a picturesque destination featuring B√°i T·ª≠ Long National Park, boat tours, and numerous small islands. reviews.text: Serene, peaceful and tranquil. Bai Tu Long Bay is absolutely beautiful and worthwhile venturing out to. There are hundreds of mountains around the bay protecting the waters with some with caves you can trek into. Kayaking around this bay around sunset is unreal.

Further north and east of Halong Bay so fewer day trippers. More secluded yet as beautiful as Halong Bay. Tip: if you can spare the time, a 3 day 2 night boat trip gives you time to appreciate the magnificence of this World Heritage area to the fullest

Bai Tu Long is a beautiful area protected by hundreds of islands. The scenery is tranquil and out of this world. I have never seen anything quite like it. I highly recommend a longer 3-day - 2-night cruise to escape the massive crowds within Halong Bay.

places.generalDescription: Ba Trai Dao, also known as the Three Peaches, is a group of three small islands rising dramatically from the turquoise waters of Halong Bay. Legend has it that these islands were once peaches stolen from heaven by a fairy to grant immortality to a poor fisherman she loved. The King of Heaven turned them into the craggy mounts seen today in his anger. These foliage-covered rocks offer secluded sandy beaches perfect for kayaking and swimming.

sources.snippet: If Titov and Soi Sim are the 2 most famous sandy beaches on Halong Bay, Ba Trai Dao and Van Boi Beach are the two most beautiful ones on Lan Ha Bay. Since Titov and Soi Sim are surrounded by many islands, and own a huge dock for parking, all the big and small boats can access easily which makes the beach more crowded. However, it is definitely worth visiting thanks to the soft sandy beach and an amazing 360-degree view from the top of the island.

sources.snippet: Compared to the destinations mentioned above, Ba Trai Dao Islets and Beach has the smallest beach. reviews.text: When we visited in mid-November, there was a small crowd. Entry is free and open to everyone, as the beach is not privatized. It is clean, with shallow water perfect for swimming. The sand here is softer and better than Cat Co 2, with no rocks at the bottom. While Cat Co 2 has slightly clearer water, it also has a rocky bottom. A nearby market within walking distance offers great food and shopping options. You can also use a public shuttle service to the main market for just 5,000 dongs PP. The big hotel in the back ruins the view. One can use loungers, shower or pay for food and drinks from these very hotels. I personally feel bathroom and shower can be used in these hotels. It is decently charged.

When we were there the water was quite dirty. Some plastic and other things in the water. A beach chair cost 100k dong for guests not staying in the hotel. But if you want, you can just lay on the beach for free, I think. If you want to use shower you have to pay. Still it is a nice beach I would say.

It's so overcrowded, loud and dirty... Lan ha/ha long bays are beautiful but don't waste your time for staying in Cat ba for more than a night.
The picture I uploaded is from 6:30 am...

places.generalDescription: Thi√™n Canh S∆°n Beach is a hidden gem located on Hon Co Island in Bai Tu Long Bay. To reach the beach, visitors must climb about 100 stone steps, but the effort is well worth it. The main attraction here is the Grass Cave, which features unique rock formations resembling animals, mythical beings, and flowers. Inside the cave, the walls and stalactites glisten like stars in the night sky when illuminated.

reviews.text:
Our 2 day 1 night on the Dragon Legend cruise with Indochina Junk was flawless from pick up to drop off.

We did so much research to find this tour and it all paid off. The boat was clean & our rooms were spotless, with a large comfortable bed, air-con and a mini fridge.

The bay wasn't crowded and there was little to no litter in the water where they took us.

The drivers were polite, they drove us safely to and from the tour in a clean comfortable mini bus.
The organisation of the tour was exceptional, our English speaking tour guide Long always kept us informed and answered all of our questions.

All of the staff on board the Dragon Legend were friendly & helpful and made our stay an enjoyable experience.

The food was brilliant, multiple courses for lunch and dinner, so we tired so much amazing sea food. The breakfast and brunch on the second day was also Great with a really wide range of choice, You could carry on going up buffet style until you were full.
The staff constantly topped up our water and made sure we were satisfied. The cocktails were brilliant and they would come and find you on the deck once they had made your drink.

You must try the Vietnamese coffee onboard this was also really good.

Honestly our only regret was that we didn't book a longer stay with them. I would happy go back and stay on the Dragon Legend again and I would recommend it to anyone.

We did the 3 day 2 night tour on the Dragon Pearl 1 and had an amazing time - it was definitely a highlight of our Vietnam trip!  Peter, our guide, was fantastic!  He was very knowledgeable and had the best energy.  The ship staff is so kind and accommodating as well.  The food and drink on the boat are amazing - you will not go hungry!  Great itinerary, I'm glad we did the 3 day tour because it allowed us to see more and enjoy a bit of a slower pace.  Would definitely recommend Indochina Junk, they're a very well run company.

We did the 2-day, 3-night Dragon Legend Cruise with Indochina Junk and had the most unforgettable time:)

Our cabin was a dream! Beautifully designed with a cozy, elegant interior and a bathtub facing a huge window with the most stunning views. Taking a bath while watching the limestone cliffs glide by was something truly special.

The boat was beautiful in every corner, with a calm and quiet atmosphere that made the whole experience feel luxurious and relaxed.

The staff were incredibly friendly and professional, always smiling and ready to help, and our guide Kenny was truly amazing -knowledgeable, kind and made every part of the trip enjoyable.

We loved the mix of activities, kayaking, cave visits, and just enjoying the peaceful scenery. Every meal was delicious, fresh, and thoughtfully presented. Even as a vegetarian I received my own menu with the most delicious meals and felt really well taken care of.

If you're looking for a more intimate, off-the-beaten-path cruise with comfort and heart, Indochina Junk is the best choice. We are so thankful for the experience and will always remember it!

reviews.text:
This indeed the last remains of floating village  which indeed at present is 23 families from that of 200+.

- You would able to see the problems faced by them as well as the life around this place. Potable water is the biggest concern.

- Most of them are fisherman and currently due to tourism they took up the role of boatman/boatwoman which is better paying than fishing.

- Overall good experience to understand the life in middle of water and mountains.

Very peaceful floating fishing village situated in limestone islands. This place is sheltered from the constant motor sounds of the tour and tender boats.  Once you board a row boat, all the sound disappears and and all that can be heard is birds calling and the sound of the oars stirring the water.  The views are great and the rowers will take the boats very close to the rocks giving brief chances to see sea life.

Floating village is an eye opener. They were once uneducated until the government stepped in to support them buy offering free education and houses on land. But they didnt last on land long and moved back to the floating village. They survive on tourism and their fishing although stocks appear to be dwindling. Make sure you give them a good tip as they only get one tour per day. Yes that one boat ride is only chance they have to earn money.
